chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of male urethritis
chapter.summary: Covers the management of male urethritis.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 13 years onwards (Male).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a man with suspected urethritis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Offer referral to all men with suspected urethritis to a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic or other local specialist sexual health service for treatment. if referral is declined or not possible:

  • Offer empirical treatment for chlamydial infection with doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 7 days. Where doxycycline is contraindicated or not tolerated, possible alternatives are:
    • Azithromycin 1 gram, single dose for 1 day then 500mg daily for 2 days (Note: people taking azithromycin should be advised to abstain from sexual intercourse until 14 days after the start of treatment, and until symptoms have resolved). 
    • Ofloxacin 200mg twice daily or 400mg daily for 7 days.
  • If gonococcal urethritis is suspected (for example if there is a local outbreak of gonorrhoea), consider treating for gonorrhoea. For more information, see the CKS topic on Gonorrhoea.
  • If trichomoniasis is suspected (for example if the man's partner has trichomoniasis), treat for trichomoniasis. For more information see the CKS topic on Trichomoniasis.
  • As well as screening for possible underlying causes of urethritis, screen for other STIs including syphilis and Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) — for more information, see the CKS topics on Syphilis and HIV infection and AIDS.
  • Consider screening for hepatitis if the person is at high risk. For more information, see the CKS topics on Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C.
  • If a urinary tract infection is suspected (for example if the man has urinary symptoms and a urine dipstick is positive for nitrite and leukocyte esterase), send a mid-stream urine sample for culture and sensitivity and treat as appropriate — for further information, see the CKS topic on Urinary tract infection (lower) - men.
  • Give advice about:
    • The most likely cause of urethritis which is usually, but not always, due to an STI.
    • The importance of adhering to treatment, as well as possible side effects.
    • Abstaining from sex (including oral sex) until he has completed treatment and treatment has also been completed by his partner(s).
    • The importance of safer sexual practices in reducing the future risk of acquiring STIs (for example the consistent and correct use of condoms, minimizing the number of sexual partners).
      • Note: patient information leaflets on male urethritis are available from the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) and the Family Planning Association.
  • Advise the person that all their recent sexual partner(s) should be notified and advised to attend a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic. 
  • Arrange follow-up 1-2 weeks after treatment:
    • Review the person for persistent symptoms which may indicate treatment failure.
    • Confirm that contact tracing has been carried out. The duration of contact tracing varies:
      • For men who have tested positive for chlamydia, see the CKS topic Chlamydia - uncomplicated genital.
      • For men who have tested positive for gonorrhoea, see the CKS topic Gonorrhoea.
      • For all other men, the recommended duration is all partners within the previous 4 weeks.
    • Discuss the results of the STI screen and manage appropriately. For more information on detailed management see the CKS topics on Gonorrhoea, Chlamydia - uncomplicated genital, Trichomoniasis, HIV infection and AIDS, Syphilis, Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of urethritis are largely based on expert opinion in the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline on the management of non-gonococcal urethritis [BASHH, 2015a], an update to this guideline which recommends use of doxycycline first-line [BASHH, 2018], and the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) and BASHH guideline Sexually Transmitted Infections in Primary Care [RCGP, 2013].

Offering empirical antibiotic treatment
  • The recommendation to treat empirically for Chlamydia trachomatis is based on expert opinion from Scottish guidelines Urethral Discharge (Males) [NHS Lothian, 2008]. It is not possible to accurately clinically distinguish between gonococcal urethritis and non-gonococcal urethritis. However, chlamydia is the infection most commonly associated with urethritis. Empirical treatment alleviates symptoms, reduces ongoing transmission and halts the spread of infection [RCGP, 2013].
Use of doxycycline first-line
  • Doxycycline is recommended as first-line treatment for non-gonococcal urethritis to avoid macrolide resistance in Mycoplasma genitalium (Mgen). BASHH states that 'The prevalence of pre-treatment macrolide resistance in Mgen in the United Kingdom is almost certainly >40%, which is probably due to the widespread use of azithromycin 1g to treat STIs and the limited availability of diagnostic tests for Mgen. Treatment with doxycycline reduces the Mgen load and risk of azithromycin selecting and/or inducing macrolide resistance' [BASHH, 2018].
Trichomoniasis
  • The recommendation to consider treating for trichomoniasis if this is has been confirmed in the man's sexual partner is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Screening for hepatitis
  • The recommendation to consider screening for hepatitis screening is based on expert opinion in the BASHH guideline Summary guidance on tests for sexually transmitted infections [BASHH, 2015b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage treatment failure?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If symptoms persist or recur after treatment is completed, strongly advise the person to attend a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic or other local specialist sexual health service. If this is declined or not possible:
    • Check adherence to the drug treatment regime.
    • Exclude the possibility of re-infection. Check that current partner(s) have been treated appropriately and simultaneously.
    • Reconsider the diagnosis. Ensure that other causes of symptoms or alternative diagnoses have been excluded.
    • If treated with doxycycline regimen first line, then prescribe Azithromycin 1g stat then 500 mg once daily for the next 2 days, plus metronidazole 400mg twice daily for five days.
    • Azithromycin should be started within 2 weeks of finishing doxycycline.
    • Patients should be advised to abstain from sexual intercourse until 14 days after the start of treatment and until symptoms have resolved.
    • If treated with azithromycin regimen first line, then prescribe Moxifloxacin 400mg once daily for 10 days, plus metronidazole 400mg twice daily for five days.
      • Or alternatively, prescribed Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 7 days, plus metronidazole 400mg twice daily for five days. (Note: if Mycoplasma genitalium detection assays have not been carried out and a negative result has not been confirmed, consider trying this regimen rather then using moxifloxacin).
    • If symptoms persist despite a second course of antibiotics, seek specialist advice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on managing treatment failure for urethritis are largely based on expert opinion in the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) UK national guideline on the management of non-gonococcal urethritis [BASHH, 2015a], a partial update to this guideline which alters some treatment recommendations [BASHH, 2018], and the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) and BASHH guideline Sexually Transmitted Infections in Primary Care [RCGP, 2013].

Referral to genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic or other local specialist sexual health service
  • The recommendation to strongly advise referral for all men with persistent or recurrent urethritis is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice. Establishing an accurate diagnosis of ongoing urethritis is central to management and can usually only be undertaken by a trained specialist.
  • The cause of persistent or recurrent urethritis following treatment is complex and poorly understood and thought to be multifactorial. An infective cause has been identified in less than 50% of cases. Mycoplasma genitalium infection has been identified in 20–40% of men with persistent or recurrent urethritis and Ureaplasma urealyticum has also been implicated [BASHH, 2015a].
Seeking specialist advice
  • The recommendation to seek specialist advice if symptoms persist after a second course of antibiotics is pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
